title: 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) Scandal
summary: The sovereign fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) was systematically embezzled via a global web of shell companies, implicating top Malaysian officials and international banks.
content: Between 2009 and 2014, 1MDB raised debt and made investments which eventually were found to have been diverted through shell companies and offshore bank accounts. In 2015 media investigations started and by 2018 major legal actions commenced; several countries’ authorities participated. The scandal exposed weaknesses in governance, banking-oversight and international money-laundering controls.

title: “Macau Scam” Telephone Fraud in Malaysia
loss: Hundreds of thousands to millions of MYR per case
summary: The so-called Macau Scam involves callers impersonating courier companies, police/law enforcement or banks, intimidating victims into transferring funds or OTPs to so-called safe accounts.
content: In Malaysia the Macau Scam appears via spoofed calls or messages, where the victim is told they are under investigation or have items (e.g., credit cards) under their name. They are then coerced to transfer money to accounts controlled by the scammers. For example, a vegetable farmer in Pahang lost about RM792,669 after such a call.

title: Cryptocurrency Investment Fraud in Malaysia (2023-2024)
summary: Malaysian authorities arrested suspects linked to fake crypto investment platforms, where victims were promised high returns but funds were stolen and laundered via blockchain. One case involved Malaysian police arresting three men accused of stealing over US$2.5 million via crypto fraud.
content: In early 2024, the Royal Malaysia Police (RMP) made arrests in a case where fraudsters offered victims up to 50% returns via a crypto investment scheme; the funds were stolen and traced via blockchain forensics. Between 2019-2023 over 5,500 crypto investment fraud cases with losses totalling around RM417 million were reported.

title: Human-Trafficked Malaysians Forced in Scam Centres in Peru (2023)
summary: At least 43 Malaysians were trafficked to Peru and forced to work in a tele-scam/online scam centre, before being rescued by police authorities.
content: In October 2023, Peruvian police raided a house in La Molina (Lima) and rescued 43 Malaysian citizens aged between 18–36 who were forced to make scam calls or conduct online fraud. The victims had been lured via overseas job offers. This case highlights the link between cross-border organised crime, human trafficking and online fraud syndicates.

title: Large-Scale Scam Call Centre Raid in Bangsar South (2025)
loss: Estimated hundreds of millions of MYR (investigation ongoing)
summary: Malaysian police conducted one of the country’s largest raids of a scam call-centre hub in Bangsar South, Kuala Lumpur, arresting over 400 individuals in August 2025.
content: The raid uncovered a five-storey office allegedly housing over 400 staff conducting scam operations targeting victims across multiple countries. The case underscores the industrial-scale fraud operations now operating in Malaysia, linked to fintech and international syndicates.

title: Research & Trend Reports on Scam Governance in Malaysia (2024-2025)
summary: Academic and government-linked institutions in Malaysia and Southeast Asia have released reports showing that scams are increasingly cross-border, tech-driven (including AI), and that policy/governance responses need strengthening.
content: Publications indicate that scams now make up large portions of fraud cases in Malaysia; for example, one study estimated losses of RM54.02 billion (≈US$12.8 billion) in 2024-type data, representing about 3% of Malaysia’s GDP. The reports emphasise the need for regulatory overhaul, telecom/fin-tech cooperation and public awareness.

title: Cross-Border Asset Recovery & International Co-operation (1MDB example)
summary: Major fraud cases in Malaysia – such as 1MDB – show that tracing and recovering assets requires multi-country coordination, civil and criminal proceedings, and long time-frames.
content: The 1MDB scandal’s global dimension involved countries such as the US, Switzerland, Singapore and others. Legal actions include civil suits, asset freezing and returns. The difficulty and length of recovery underscore the international complexity of large-scale financial crime.

title: AI-enabled Voice & Deepfake Scams Emerging in Malaysia (2025)
loss: Thousands to tens of thousands of MYR per case (and rising)
summary: Recent reporting shows scams in Malaysia using AI voice-cloning to impersonate employers or trusted persons, tricking victims into transfers.
content: In August 2025, a Malay Mail article detailed how a woman in Selangor lost RM5,000 when a caller used AI-cloned voice of her employer via phone/WhatsApp, requesting Touch ‘n Go PINs. The incident indicates the next wave of fraud combining social engineering with AI technology.
